container why all of a sudden we start having network connection failures because somebody started to do a port
scan or something like that so we extended Falco to support kubernetes audit events it's a new feature in
kubernetes 111 and what it does is it provides this chronological set of
records documenting changes to the cluster so in layman's terms anytime somebody does something through
the Kubb API server an audit event will get triggered this can go into a log file you can also
tell it to go into a web hook as well and each record is a JSON object which
I'll show you here in a second and then there's something also called audit policy an audit policy basically lets
you set how noisy is that event stream so do you want to log everything or maybe do you only want to log things
where the response was the the request was successful for instance there's a
new feature in 113 kubernetes 113 it's
an alpha feature and it's called audit sinks so the log file and web hook and
even audit policy before 113 had to be configured on the master and the problem
with configuring it on the master is that if you're running in something like e KS or g ke or some other managed
kubernetes service you don't get access to the master and so therefore you can't drop files on to the master to configure
the log file and webhook audit sync is a way to fix that to where you can actually apply a kubernetes manifest via
the API server and you can configure audit policy that way and by the way
it's sync like you're pouring it down the sink not sy NC so this is what an audit of it
